data.title: Introduce a move command for moving cursor in the editor
data.body:
Introduce a move command for moving cursor at a logical view position in the editor

This will allow the extension writers to place the cursor at a provided position in the editor

Usage:
- Command Id: `cursorMove`
- Arguments: `{to: $ViewPosition, select: boolean, by: $By, value: number}`
- Defaults: `value` =  1. `by` based on `to` value.

**ViewPosition**
- `left`: Moves the cursor left by `n` characters.
- `right`: Moves the cursor right by `n` characters. 
- `up`: Moves the cursor up by `n` lines or wrapped lines.
- `down`: Moves the cursor down by `n` lines or wrapped lines. 
- `wrappedLineStart`: Places the cursor at the start of the current line in the view.
- `wrappedLineFirstNonWhitespaceCharacter`: Places the cursor at the first non white space character of the current line in the view.
- `wrappedLineEnd`: Places the cursor at the end of the current line in the view.
- `wrappedLineLastNonWhitespaceCharacter`: Places the cursor at the last non white space character of the current line in the view.
- `wrappedLineColumnCenter`: Places the cursor at the center of the line in the view.
- `viewPortTop`: Move the cursor to the first non white space character of Nth line from the top of the view.
- `viewPortCenter`: Move the cursor to the first non white space character of the center line of the view.
- `viewPortBottom`: Move the cursor to the first non white space character of Nth line from the bottom of the view.

**By**
- `line` - Default for line specific commands
- `wrappedLine`
- `character` - Default for character specific commands
- `halfLine` - Only for character specific commands.

Set `select` arg to `true`, to select text for above

milestone.title: Backlog

data.title: Replace doesn't work with regex lookahead or lookbehind
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Windows 7 SP1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Highlight string "A B C D E F"
2. Search string "\s(?=\w)" replace string "\n"
3. Click replace all button.

Nothing changes.  Note that the spaces between the letters do match and the parser will cycle through them with the arrow buttons.  If you change to lookbehind (i.e. move the whitespace to the end) nothing will match.

data.title: Suggestion: Markdown settings for highlightjs theme

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
The markdown extension uses `highlight.js` for code highlighting, which comes with many themes inside its `styles` folder.

Yet, the default theme (`tomorrow.css`) is hardcoded here:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/markdown/src/extension.ts#L237

It is possible to override this by finding and copying the theme you like into your project and referencing the file with `markdown.styles` settings. This work but it's not easy/intuitive and it does not actually remove the `tomorrow` rules/stylesheet from the document (which can provide some unwanted defaults).

I suggest that you make the default theme easily changeable with a new settings, maybe `markdown.highlightStyle: "tomorrow"` and support all the hightlight.js built-in styles.

BTW I think `tomorrow` is a _very colorful_ choice for a default settings, but that's just my taste.

data.title: Go To Definition should support Webpack resolve paths
data.body:
Currently Go To Definition works perfectly well for relative paths within application, eg:

```
import something from './something'
```

However, after I add some resolve paths in Webpack config, like

```
  resolve: {
    root: [
      path.resolve(rootPath, 'app/frontend/lib'),
```

I can import files like this

```
import something from 'something'
// instead of 
// import something from 'app/frontend/lib/something' or
// import something from '../../lib/something'
```

The problem is that VSCode won't follow these resolve paths.

The solution could be to add configuration which will define additional resolve paths for Go To Definition functionality.

data.title: TypeScript generic syntax highlighting is incorrect
feature parity between DecorationRenderOptions and ThemableDecorationAttachmentRenderOptions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0

I would like to see more feature parity between `DecorationRenderOptions` and `ThemableDecorationAttachmentRenderOptions` to whatever extent is possible.

If there is a particular reason why one supports a styling property that the other does not, what are the limitations and is overcoming them on the roadmap? (Some differences, like `contentText`, are obvious and do not need an explanation.)
1. `DecorationRenderOptions` allows setting all of the various border styles independently, while `ThemableDecorationAttachmentRenderOptions` provides only a `border` property, which does not allow different styles for top, left, right, and bottom.
2. Only `DecorationRenderOptions` has outline styles.
3. Only `ThemableDecorationAttachmentRenderOptions` has `margin`.
4. Only `ThemableDecorationAttachmentRenderOptions` has `height` or `width`; are these solely used for the dimensions of `contentIconPath`?

data.title: TypeScript Intellisense sometimes lose track of project definitions.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

I don't have a way to reliably reproduce when I observe this, but I wanted to describe it:

I have a project where I use typings to manage definitions for third party libs. (https://github.com/typings/typings)

This saves me from having to use reference comments in every file - instead I rely on `import` statements entirely. 

This works well in VSC - at least when I initially open the project folder. Then after some while I start to get complains from Intellisense that objects and/or properties doesn't exists. These are stem from the definitions from `typings`. But by just restarting VSC the intellisense works fine again - for a while.

I've yet not been able to determine what trigger the intellisense to stop using the `typings` definitions during a session.

The compiler never run into issues - it's just the intellisense that fail after a while in a running session.

Anyone else experienced this? Or have any suggestions to what I can try to debug or create a reliable repro case?

Here is a screen capture that shows the bug in action - intellisense fails to pick up on my third party references. Then I close and reopen the project - and everything works again:

![visualstudiocodeintellisensebug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/192418/16766845/adac8f40-483c-11e6-8713-717c01f4ce62.gif)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is a feature-request. 

A common use case for me in Eclipse, is to double click on the right after a brace or a curly brace, to select all the content inside it. It's a fast way to select, indent, remove the content. It's a lot more handy to see the ending curly brace (especially for JS and other functionnally langugage). 

![www gifcreator me_zovlan](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3749428/16766721/07e53fda-483c-11e6-91dd-f108628db010.gif)

data.title: Allow to 'resolve' a SymbolInformation
data.body:
Working on a Java language server...

`WorkspaceSymbolProvider.provideWorkspaceSymbols` returns a set of `SymbolInformation` where each SymbolInformation contains a location, including the source range of the element.

The problem is that acquiring the source range of an element is quite expensive in our case, as it requires opening the document that contains the symbol. (The symbol index we have does not contain source ranges).
As the open symbol action doesn't really need the range until the user selects a symbol to be opened, it would be good if the API would have an additional hook that allows to resolve a SymbolInformation element, similar to what is there for CompletionResults.

But it disables `find in selection` by default since June_2016 update.

---

Could I revive the previous behavior?
I could not find the setting by searching in the default setting file by `find`, `search` or `select`.
My 2 cents, the new behavior is inconvenient for me.

data.title: Create additional syntaxes/grammars for catering for the various SQL variants
data.body:
Getting into SQL dev now, I see that although largely the same, there are some important syntax differences between the popular SQL implementations in Oracle, PostgreSQL, MySQL and T-SQL (Microsoft SQL Server).

This issue is evident here e.g. https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5223

I propose that additional syntax files are added to the sql extension. Other projects are also facing the same issue e.g. https://github.com/atom/language-sql/issues/40 & https://github.com/textmate/sql.tmbundle

data.title: Addition of GO INTO T-SQL syntax
data.body:
GO is used as a separator of batches of statemements in SQL Server which uses T-SQL
SELECT ... INTO is used as a CTAS (Create Table AS) of sorts in T-SQL.
